data.title: "Death To Plastic" misleads
data.body: Primarily misleading in how it implies plastic-free products while he actually sells plastic-lined products

data.title: Company Mission
data.body: The company's mission is to reduce worldwide plastic use

data.title: Plastic Use
data.body:
The company has plastic in most or all of its products

Needs Type 2 connection showing marketing has led customers to expect plastic-free products

data.title: Better alternatives exist
data.body:
The examples given are Glass and Stainless Steel.

Responded to: 
[[N09yXC0wBRK1|Mike Cessario: Aluminum is the only option]]
[[idxVkJfd8hZl|Mike Cessario: People are not seriously concerned about liquid touching plastic]]
[[bdFGHra0nzdw|Mike Cessario: Plastic in Cans has no effect on recyclability]]

data.title: Examples
data.body: Can Lining, powder packs

data.title: Market expectations
data.body:
People think that "death to plastic" means they are buying plastic-free products.

Needs Type 2 connection showing LD does not sell plastic-free products.

Responded to:
[[8401yf9w|Mike Cessario: DTP is a marketing tagline]]
[[xj5Ea3KE1v5f|Mike Cessario: Marketing supported waste message]]
[[X3K3fIAQTRaC|Mike Cessario: Shorthand]]

data.title: Personal Experience
data.body: He bought thousands worth of LD for health / microplastic purposes

data.title: Company Origin
data.body: The world in 2018 was focused on plastic waste, and so the company's mission was about plastic waste

data.title: Marriot
data.body: Marriot and other hotel chains were getting rid of plastic straws

data.title: China Stopped Accepting
data.body: China stopped accepting plastic waste in 2018 and American companies began sending it to landfills

data.title: New Awareness
data.body: People in 2018 were becoming aware that plastic was not actually recyclable

data.title: Aluminum is the only option
data.body:
Responded to: 
[[YXM058toX8IO|Tim Pool: Better alternatives exist]]

data.title: Aluminum is only economic recyclable option
data.body:
Aluminum can be sold for $1500/ton, where plastics and glass are worthless

Needs Type 2 links to explanations for both ecological and health factors.

data.title: Aluminum is the only sustainable option
data.body:
Aluminum is the only viable option to infinitely reuse

Needs type 2 links to explanations for both economic and health factors.

data.title: Marketing supported waste message
data.body:
Responded to:
[[PRfATbP7XNik|Tim Pool: Market expectations]]

data.title: Gave to plastic waste charities
data.body: Originally gave 5% (43:00)

data.title: Shorthand
data.body:
"Death to Plastic" is reasonably understood as shorthand for "Death to Plastic Bottles"


Responded to:
[[PRfATbP7XNik|Tim Pool: Market expectations]]

data.title: They are a beverage company
data.body: The context implies plastic bottles

data.title: Surveys
data.body: Recent surveys showed 80% of users thought it was about plastic waste

data.title: Microplastic Awareness is New
data.body:
The concern about microplastics is so new that a phrase like "Death to Plastic" could not be interpreted as a reference to microplastics.


Responded to:
[[PRfATbP7XNik|Tim Pool: Market expectations]]

data.title: Dearth of Research
data.body: There is little scientific consensus on what these are, where they are, what the effects are, etc

data.title: People are not seriously concerned about liquid touching plastic
data.body:
Responded to:
[[YXM058toX8IO|Tim Pool: Better alternatives exist]]

data.title: French Study
data.body: A French study found that water in glass bottles has more microplastics than (aluminum bottles?) because of the cap sealer

data.title: Glass bottles use more plastic
data.body: 10x aluminum cans

data.title: Plastic in Cans has no effect on recyclability
data.body:
Responded to:
[[YXM058toX8IO|Tim Pool: Better alternatives exist]]

data.title: Burns off
data.body: The plastic lining is microns thick so when the cans are smelted the plastic gets completely burned off.

data.title: Plastic in cans creates landfill waste
Process breakdown
data.body: Even if perfectly filtered, smelted plastic ends up in filters which eventually end up in landfills.

data.title: LD cans are not infinitely recyclable
Assumptive Reasoning
data.body: LD is making people believe something that haven't exactly claimed

data.title: Definitions
data.body: Infinitely recyclable does not mean 100% infinitely recyclable.

data.title: Personal Experience
data.body: Him and associates regularly reuse glass bottles

data.title: LD has bad intentions
data.body:
LD is positioning itself as eco-friendly / healthy while not seriously pursuing either goal.

Responded to:
[[aDSFmEKUse5R|Mike Cessario: Company Origin]]
[[bdFGHra0nzdw|Mike Cessario: Plastic in Cans has no effect on recyclability]]

data.title: LD is not displacing water bottles
Major brands are failing
data.body: Most major bottled water brands are seeing a decrease in sales

data.title: New Company
data.body: LD is still small, thus not causing major displacement

data.title: Still water small part
data.body: Only 10-15% of sales are from still water

data.title: Smart Water
data.body: Smart Water is the only major brand not seeing a decrease in sales, and they are shifting toward aluminum bottles

data.title: Overall sales way up
data.body: Plastic water bottle sales are rising exponentially.

data.title: No more packs
data.body: They stopped selling "Death Dust"

data.title: Packets might reduce overall waste
data.body: If people are wasting a tiny packet worth of plastic instead of a whole gatorade bottle, it will waste less

data.title: Coke bottles are not recyclable
data.body: Coke owns the shape of the glass bottle, so you can't commercially reuse.

data.title: Glass is not Sustainable
data.body:
Part of any big picture sustainability project is having infinitely recyclable materials.  Single use items like glass bottles can never be part of the long term vision

Needs Type 2 link showing answer for other vessels (SS)

data.title: Glass is ok in landfills
data.body: Glass is just rocks, so filling up landfills with glass is not a problem in the way plastic is.

data.title: Energy
data.body: It takes less energy to make new glass than to recycle

data.title: Displacing Glass
data.body: LD might be displacing glass instead of displacing plastic

data.title: No evidence
data.body: He claims Pool's only evidence is his personal opinion.

data.title: Glass bottle have more plastic
data.body:
Glass bottles have more plastic in their cap sealers and their stickers than LD cans.

Needs Type 2 link showing an answer for microplastics

data.title: Some vessels have less or no plastic
data.body: Silicon top and paper sticker could have no plastic

data.title: Exotic bottling options are not financially viable
data.body: No bottle except alcohol at $15 can budget for a cork

data.title: LD is an expensive product
data.body: It's expensive enough to justify something better.

data.title: Personal Experience
data.body: He shopped around and can get plastic bottled water for 0.8c/oz and LD for 8-16c/oz = 8x cost

data.title: Distribution Costs
data.body: Products like LD have to go through distributers to get to retail. The only ones they can use are Beer distributers.  They want 30%.  Companies like LD need at  least 30% gross margin. Retail wants 35% profit. Giants like coke own all this in house.

data.title: Slogan Change
data.body: Death to Plastic was appropriate in the past, but in today's climate it's time to change it to "Death to Plastic Bottles"

data.title: Timing of change implies insincerity
data.body: This change was only made after the company went negative virally, despite years of concerns with microplastics etc

data.title: Viral image
data.body: They didn't make the distinction clear when they had a positive viral moment with a plastic bottle and a LD bottle

data.title: Articles
data.body: Articles from 3 years ago called out LD for plastic liners

data.title: Few people have problem
data.body: Internal data shows that few of their customers are unhappy with the plastic in the cans.  They didn't feel the need to address such a niche group until this blew up virally

data.title: LD is dishonest in an FTC way
data.body: Death to Plastic is misleading in a similar way to how Red Bull Gives You Wings was found to be by the FTC.

data.title: Internal vs External Messaging
data.body: Saying Death to Plastic while knowing that some of their customers thought that meant no plastic in the products fits the fact pattern with Red Bull

data.title: DTP is a Point of View
Recent ad
data.body: Their recent ad with Whitney Cummings was about recycling, not health.

data.title: Double Meaning of Ad
data.body: Tim, seemingly in jest, speculates that the ad, which was comically about stuffing plastic into your body, was giving a secret nod to microplastics leeching into your body.

data.title: Still not perfect
data.body: Even with a perfect glass bottle, the water will still touch plastic in the factory and other points in the supply chain.  Every option has microplastics

data.title: Glass bottles actually have less plastic
data.body: He reads something saying pop caps have 0.03-0.05g of plastic (which is less than an earlier cited number for the LD cans)

data.title: Mineragua
data.body: Comparable price to LD

data.title: Starting naivete
data.body: Tim understands how they could have started without thinking about microplastics

data.title: Treatment of Skaters
data.body: Mike Cessario betrayed the skate team by cutting off their sponsorship after they were with him from the beginning.

data.title: Total Cost
data.body:
The whole skate team cost $40,000/yr which should have been worth the loyalty from such a big company.
Referenced again at 56:00

data.title: PR agency
data.body: Once they had a real marketing budget, he couldn't justify giving money to his friends when they weren't even tracking performance.

data.title: Argument Summary
data.body:
The practices and intentions of LD demonstrate a pattern of dishonesty, specifically regarding the phrase "Death to Plastic".
They could be selling products with less plastic and doing more to disclose their current plastic use but chose to knowingly deceive its customers deliberately.

data.title: Argument Summary
data.body: The focus of the company has always been on waste, any any failure to disclose was because concerns related to non-waste issues were trivial until recently.

data.title: Didn't say Death to All Plastic
No evidence
data.body: There is no evidence that LD is displacing more plastic bottles than glass bottles.

data.title: DTP is a marketing tagline
data.body:
This is not a claim, it's like Just do it or Gives you Wings

Responded to:
[[PRfATbP7XNik|Tim Pool: Market expectations]]

data.title: LD is acting like a standard bev company
Same plastic footprint
data.body: Can for can, they produce the same amount of plastic as standard soda companies.

data.title: Moving into Soft Drinks
data.body: Them moving more into soft drinks is them behaving less disruptively to plastic.

data.title: Glass bottles use a lot of plastic
data.body:
Glass bottle caps have ~3g of plastic.
Can liner is 0.5g.
Another couple grams of plastic on most glass bottle labels.
5-6g total.

data.title: LD is a contributor to the plastic market, not a disrupter
Implies 100%
data.body: Infinitely recyclable gives the impression that the can is 100% aluminum and can be fully infinitely recycled

data.title: Stretching
data.body: By saying that the cans are not infinitely recyclable, Tim Pool is "stretching"

data.title: Earlier Statements show LD is ok lying to customers
data.body: Earlier in the debate, Cessario admitted some people thought the products were plastic free. Even if that is a small percentage, there are certainly some people, like Tim, reaching the wrong conclusion as a net result of all their marketing, branding, etc.

data.title: Inconsitent Statements
data.body: LD (via its CEO) has been inconsistent in statements on charitable donations.

data.title: Disproven Claim
data.body: Cessario said the company never had "10% to charity" on its website, then Pool showed him an archived copy of the website with that claim.

data.title: Few donations
data.body: The amount of donations seems small relative to the size of the company.

data.title: Main charity is small
data.body: 5 Gyres is the main charity LD talks about, and the most recent IRS forms show a total of 1.2 mil in 2023

data.title: There are not many charities in this space
Not profitable
data.body: LD cannot donate much because it is still not profitable.

data.title: Body Armor
data.body: Body Armor had to reach $800 mil revenue before they hit profitability.

data.title: Skaters gave great value
data.body: Richie always made sure to get LD cans in Tim Pool videos.

data.title: Never sponsored skaters
data.body: The company never attempted to compete in the skating arena because it was dominated by energy drinks.

data.title: LD did right by the skaters
TV Show
data.body: LD paid $20k to a skater for a show that failed, and they kept paying him his regular fee for years after.

data.title: The skaters thanked him
data.body:
Many of the skaters expressed positive sentiment at the end of the sponsorship.
Richie was the only disgruntled skater.
